guide.title: Gentoo Linux ScreenShots!
guide.abstract: Screenshots of Gentoo Linux in action. Whee!

chapter.title: Here they are... click for larger PNG versions!

body.p: The screenshots on this page are contributed by various Gentoo users. Information about the used themes, background images, etc. is not available through Gentoo. You will need to contact the author of the screenshot (if you can find this person) for more information.
You can always try locating the authors on our #gentoo chat channel on irc.freenode.net or through the gentoo forums.

William has been using Gentoo for 9 months after 2 years of using Mandrake. His main window manager has always been englightenment, which you can see demonstrated on this screenshot. You'll also find a wallpaper from Cognitive Distortion and icon's downloaded from the Gentoo website.

Alex' is a fresh Gentoo user, with his first experiences dating from October 2004 when he discovered Gentoo on the DVD that accompanied his Linux Format magazine. On his screenshot you'll find KDE 3.3.1 and Eterm 0.9.2 tailing his servers' message log. You'll also find gdesklets and calender, Kopete and gkrellm on the sides of his desktop.

Eric's desktop runs XFCE4 as window manager and ROX2 for file managing and desktop icons. On the right you see anjuta editing the sourcecode of fbgrab. Also note that the XFCE4 panel has an applet that monitors the wireless connection to Eric's home network.

Joao has recently started using Linux; after 4 months of fiddling in slackware he's now a happy Gentoo'er. His screenshot shows how little changes to the theme and window environment can make a big difference.

Here is Jason's desktop showing Openbox with the 'Twice' theme. He is using vim to edit java-config, XMMS, a root tail of a couple of system logs and gkrellm with a bunch of plugins (xmms, weather, screen-shooter and audio mixer plugins).

Below we are featuring Stewart's KDE desktop with Mozilla Firebird and Thunderbird, Licq and XChat. Also he is running VMWare to meet any needs he might have in Win32 platform and is monitoring his home server with log tails in transparent Eterms.
Here is Brad's desktop with Bluecurve for KDE as well as GTK. You can see that he's playing music with noatun and also running knotes - "the ultimate personal organiser".
According to Grant this is a 'fairly generic xfce4 desktop'. There is a couple of gnome terminals and irssi inside screen. knotes and licq are docked in the system tray.

Peter is showing us another xfce4 desktop with 'Tabs' theme (xfce4-3.99.2) with xfce4-mixer and xfce4-iconbox. He is running mutt from cvs inside antyaliased xterm along with mozilla-firebird-cvs, gkrellm2 with xfce4 theme and gaim.

Luke-jr is giving an example of what KDE desktop could look like. Here is what he has running: Gaim 0.64, X-Chat 2.0.3 (on #gentoo-dev), Konsole, Konqueror (Gentoo website). Also on the kicker, which is KDE's taskbar there is KMenu, a bunch of Quicklaunch buttons, MediaControl Applet, controling XMMS. In the systray there is keyboard layout applet, KOrganizer, Klipper, Volume Control, KHexClock (this is his own applet, diplsaying time/date in hex) and Clock.
